title: José Oscar Flores
text:
José Oscar "Turu" Flores Bringas (born 16 May 1971) is an Argentine retired professional <a href="association%20football">footballer</a> who played as a <a href="striker%20%28association%20football%29">striker</a>, and is a <a href="Manager%20%28association%20football%29">manager</a>.
He started his professional career with <a href="Club%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20V%C3%A9lez%20Sarsfield">Vélez Sarsfield</a> in his native country, winning seven titles during the club's successful 1990s era. He then spent the following eight years in Spain – 194 league matches and 61 goals both <a href="Spanish%20football%20league%20system">major levels</a> combined, mainly with <a href="Deportivo%20de%20La%20Coru%C3%B1a">Deportivo</a> – and also played twice for the <a href="Argentina%20national%20football%20team">Argentina national team</a>.
Playing career.
Born in <a href="Buenos%20Aires">Buenos Aires</a>, Flores started his career with <a href="Club%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20V%C3%A9lez%20Sarsfield">Club Atlético Vélez Sarsfield</a> in 1990, going on to play a major part in their most successful era in the mid-1990s. During his time at the club he won seven major titles, including three <a href="Argentine%20Primera%20Divisi%C3%B3n">national championships</a>, the <a href="1994%20Copa%20Libertadores">1994 edition</a> of the <a href="Copa%20Libertadores">Copa Libertadores</a> and the <a href="Intercontinental%20Cup%20%28football%29">Intercontinental Cup</a>.
In 1996, Flores joined <a href="UD%20Las%20Palmas">UD Las Palmas</a> in the Spanish <a href="Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n">second division</a> for a then-record sum spent by any club in that tier, 500 million <a href="Spanish%20peseta">pesetas</a>. He scored 21 goals in <a href="1997%E2%80%9398%20Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n">his second season</a>, helping the <a href="Canary%20Islands">Canary Islands</a> team qualify for the <a href="Promotion%20and%20relegation">promotion/relegation</a> playoffs, eventually lost to <a href="Real%20Oviedo">Real Oviedo</a> (4–3 on aggregate).
After his performances, Flores joined <a href="Deportivo%20de%20La%20Coru%C3%B1a">Deportivo de La Coruña</a> also in the country, alongside teammate <a href="Manuel%20Pablo">Manuel Pablo</a>. He formed an efficient striker partnership with Portuguese <a href="Pauleta">Pauleta</a> first and Dutch <a href="Roy%20Makaay">Roy Makaay</a> after, as the <a href="Galicia%20%28Spain%29">Galicians</a> won the first <a href="La%20Liga">La Liga</a> title in their history in <a href="1999%E2%80%932000%20La%20Liga">2000</a>; on 6 February of that year, he only needed 21 minutes on the pitch after coming on as a <a href="Substitute%20%28association%20football%29">substitute</a> for <a href="Djalminha">Djalminha</a> to contribute to a 5–2 home crushing of <a href="Real%20Madrid%20C.F.">Real Madrid</a>.
Flores then played for <a href="Real%20Valladolid">Real Valladolid</a>, <a href="RCD%20Mallorca">RCD Mallorca</a> and <a href="Ciudad%20de%20Murcia">Ciudad de Murcia</a> – the latter in the second level – with very little impact. In 2004, the 33-year-old returned to Argentina with <a href="Club%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20Independiente">Club Atlético Independiente</a>.
In 2006, while at <a href="Club%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20Aldosivi">Club Atlético Aldosivi</a> in his homeland's <a href="Primera%20B%20Nacional">division two</a>, Flores announced his retirement from football only to join <a href="Lyn%20Fotball">Lyn Fotball</a> in Norway in March of the following year, being joined in that adventure by compatriot <a href="Mat%C3%ADas%20Almeyda">Matías Almeyda</a>. While with the <a href="Oslo">Oslo</a> side he only played 45 minutes of a first-round <a href="Norwegian%20Football%20Cup">cup</a> match, and retired altogether shortly after.
Coaching career.
Flores returned to Vélez in 2009, being appointed <a href="Ricardo%20Gareca">Ricardo Gareca</a>'s assistant coach. On 26 December 2013, he became the manager.
Honours.
Player.
Vélez
Deportivo
Mallorca
Manager.
Vélez
